sac is initially concave dorsally and changes to a convex shape at the end of this stage.
The head bends dorsally and a gap at the anterior ventral region of the head enlarges.
A ridge forms dorsally at the posterior margin of the head.
4. l4 Stage 14: head involution and dorsal closure (ll 30 min to 13 h)
The convex protrusion of the yolk sac is covered by the serosa at the dorsal middle
region of the embryo. The germ band stretches anteriorly and a head portion involutes
into the interior of the embryo continuously with the stomodeal opening. The clypeo-
labrum is distinct. Frontal sac formation begins as the dorsal ridge moves anteriorly
covering the head region. The posterior midgut broadens dorsally. Ventral layers become
apparent and gradually flatten out along the yolk sac. The hindgut grows antero-dorsally
forming a sharper angle with the midgut. The anal plates and posterior spiracles become
distinct. Dorsal closure continues.
4.15 Stage 15: dorsal closure complete (13 to 15 h)
Head involution and dorsal closure of the ectoderm have been completed. During this
stage, dorsal closure of the musculature and gut occurs. The midgut initially assumes
a `heart shape'. Subsequently constrictions divide the midgut into three regularly spac-
ed subdivisions.
4.16 Stage 16: condensation of CNS (15 to the completion of embryonic development)
The major remaining morphogenetic movements are the condensation of the nervous
system and the conversion of the initially sac-like gut into a long convoluted tube. As
the nervous system contracts along the ventral side of the embryo, the convoluting gut
fills in the space between the posterior tip of the ventral nervous system and the anal
pads. Muscular movements begin in the gut and are soon apparent in the somatic mus-
culature as well.
5. UTIC LE PREPARATIONS
The following procedures for making cuticle prepartions are all minor variants of the
original technique described by van der Meer (24). The choice among procedures
depends on a balance between the desired quality of the preparation and the number
of different stocks and embryos to be examined.
5.1 Quick preparations of undechorionated eggs
This method may be used for determining hatch rates, embryonic phenotypes, etc.
Collect embryos and allow them to develop until all normal individuals have
hatched.
(ii) Determine the number of hatched eggs by counting the empty chorions on the
agar surface.
Pick the unhatched eggs from the plate with a forceps and transfer to a drop
of Hoyer's mountant on a glass slide.
(iv) Cover the drop with a small 10 mm) coverslip and incubate the preparation
overnight at
